quotes.topic_title: Visualization to reduce public speaking anxiety
quotes.text: Visualization is a really useful technique and you see yourself not just in the moment of speaking, but getting up to the stage, seeing it being well received, thinking about how you step off the stage.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A concrete visualization protocol that rehearses the full arc (before, during, after) rather than only the speech itself.

quotes.topic_title: Visualization to reduce public speaking anxiety
quotes.text: We see athletes do this kind of thing all the time, and there's good research to say that this desensitizes people.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Connects visualization to evidence-backed desensitization, framing it as a proven anxiety-reduction tool.

quotes.topic_title: Visualization to reduce public speaking anxiety
quotes.text: You actually have to prepare to be spontaneous.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A counterintuitive principle for on-the-spot speaking: spontaneity improves with deliberate preparation and practice.

quotes.topic_title: Visualization to reduce public speaking anxiety
quotes.text: Strive for connection over perfection by daring to be dull.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A memorable reframe that prioritizes human connection and reduces performance pressure in everyday speaking moments.

quotes.topic_title: Visualization to reduce public speaking anxiety
quotes.text: By doing that, you dial down the volume of self-evaluation, freeing up resources that can be used to really help you succeed.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Explains the mechanism: lowering self-judgment reduces cognitive load and improves real-time performance.

quotes.topic_title: Dare to be dull: connection over perfection
quotes.text: So I often say strive for connection over perfection by daring to be dull.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A memorable guiding principle that reframes speaking success around connection rather than flawless performance.

quotes.topic_title: Dare to be dull: connection over perfection
quotes.text: And if I am constantly judging and evaluating everything I am saying against some standard of perfection, whatever that is, it means I have a limited amount of bandwidth to focus on what I'm actually saying and connecting to my audience.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Explains the cognitive cost of self-judgment and why it directly harms audience connection.

quotes.topic_title: Dare to be dull: connection over perfection
quotes.text: If you have a laptop or a phone that has lots of windows and apps open, each one of those is performing less well because of the other ones being open.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A concrete mental model (CPU/bandwidth) for understanding why perfectionism degrades communication performance.

quotes.topic_title: Dare to be dull: connection over perfection
quotes.text: So dare to be dull is all about giving yourself permission to just be present and do what's needed.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Actionable advice: lower the bar to “do what’s needed” to reduce anxiety and improve presence.

quotes.topic_title: Dare to be dull: connection over perfection
quotes.text: We are often our biggest impediments to good communication because of the anxiety we bring to the party.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A counterintuitive diagnosis that the main blocker is internal (anxiety), not lack of skill or content.

quotes.topic_title: Reframe nerves as excitement
quotes.text: The human body has pretty much just one arousal response.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that explains why anxiety and excitement can be reframed as the same physiological state with different labels.

quotes.topic_title: Reframe nerves as excitement
quotes.text: So how we label the arousal matters
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A concise, actionable principle: performance can change by changing the interpretation of the same bodily signals.

quotes.topic_title: Reframe nerves as excitement
quotes.text: when we feel those symptoms of anxiety, rather than seeing it as negative, say, "This is exciting. I get to share my point of view. I get to demonstrate my value."
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A practical script practitioners can use in the moment to reframe nerves into excitement and purpose.

quotes.topic_title: Reframe nerves as excitement
quotes.text: And her research fascinatingly found that people actually were perceived as communicating better.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A research-backed, counterintuitive outcome: reframing internal arousal changes how others judge your communication quality.

quotes.topic_title: Reframe nerves as excitement
quotes.text: when you feel those anxiety symptoms, remind yourself these are signs of excitement.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable technique for converting pre-talk nerves into a performance-enhancing mindset.

quotes.topic_title: Mantras and managing negative self-talk
quotes.text: So if we can actually change that talk track, it can help us.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A simple mental model: shifting internal self-talk is a lever for improving performance and reducing nerves.

quotes.topic_title: Mantras and managing negative self-talk
quotes.text: So having some little mantra that you can say that's not over the top but just makes sense.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Practical guidance for designing mantras that feel believable and usable in real work situations.

quotes.topic_title: Mantras and managing negative self-talk
quotes.text: I was just coaching a senior leader the other day who his mantra was, "Last time this went well."
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A concrete example of a personalized mantra that counters catastrophizing by anchoring to prior success.

quotes.topic_title: Mantras and managing negative self-talk
quotes.text: Those of us who study this believe it is innate to being human to feel nervous communicating in front of others.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A normalization frame that reduces shame and pressure by treating speaking anxiety as a human default.

quotes.topic_title: Mantras and managing negative self-talk
quotes.text: For example, what would it be like if you were to start a presentation by saying, "Today I have three questions I'd like to answer. Question number one is..."
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A tactical reframe: structure presentations as a conversation (even with yourself) to lower anxiety and increase flow.

quotes.topic_title: Distract and convert presenting into conversation
quotes.text: I coached a very senior leader at Google who got very nervous when he was up in front of people, and what we did is we distract his audience.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Introduces a practical, counterintuitive tactic—reducing speaker anxiety by shifting audience attention away from the speaker.

quotes.topic_title: Distract and convert presenting into conversation
quotes.text: So he would start every single presentation saying these words, "Good morning, let's watch this video."
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, repeatable opening script that buys time and lowers pressure in the most anxious moment.

quotes.topic_title: Distract and convert presenting into conversation
quotes.text: So he went from being a presenter to being a facilitator or somebody who was having a conversation with the audience. That made him feel so much better.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Offers a memorable role-shift framework: convert presenting into facilitating to reduce nerves and increase engagement.

quotes.topic_title: Distract and convert presenting into conversation
quotes.text: Now when I say distract, I don't mean take them on a tangent that's not relevant to what you're saying, but maybe you ask them a question, maybe you tell them a story, maybe you show them a video or ask them to read something.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Clarifies how to “distract” responsibly with on-topic devices that create breathing room and audience participation.

quotes.topic_title: Distract and convert presenting into conversation
quotes.text: Yeah, most people are most nervous one minute before speaking and the first minute of speaking.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Pinpoints the highest-anxiety window, helping practitioners focus preparation on the minute before and the first minute of delivery.

quotes.topic_title: Breathing techniques and embodied cognition
quotes.text: The bottom line is this, what's critical to the relaxation response is the exhale. Lots of ways to inhale, lots of ways to exhale. You want your exhale to be longer than the inhale. The magic of the relaxation happens during the exhale.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A practical breathing principle that reframes relaxation as primarily driven by the exhale, not the inhale.

quotes.topic_title: Breathing techniques and embodied cognition
quotes.text: So I have a rule of thumb, I jokingly call it a rule of lung. You want your exhale to be twice as long as your inhale.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A memorable rule-of-thumb practitioners can apply immediately to reduce stress in the moment.

quotes.topic_title: Breathing techniques and embodied cognition
quotes.text: Breathing is very helpful in managing so many of our anxiety symptoms. It slows down the heart rate, makes our voice sound more normal because when we get nervous, we breathe shallow and that changes... Our voice is a wind instrument, it changes the way we sound, can reduce some of the shakiness.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Connects breathing mechanics to voice control, offering a concrete lever for sounding more confident while anxious.

quotes.topic_title: Breathing techniques and embodied cognition
quotes.text: There was a researcher at Duke, I think it was Duke, who... The only experimental variation that he did is he had people hold something that was cold in their hand, like an iced coffee versus a warm coffee. And then he asked the participants to make ratings of people. And if you were holding something cold, you saw the person as a colder person, as more aloof and more distant, and if you were holding something warm, you saw them as more collaborative and embracing.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A vivid embodied-cognition example showing how physical sensations can bias social judgments—useful for designing calmer, warmer interactions.

quotes.topic_title: Breathing techniques and embodied cognition
quotes.text: One that I personally think is a lot of fun is getting present oriented because when I'm in the present, by definition I'm not worried about the future.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A simple mental model for anxiety reduction: shift attention to the present to short-circuit future-focused worry.

quotes.topic_title: Tongue twisters, warmups, and strategic swearing
quotes.text: One that I personally think is a lot of fun is getting present oriented because when I'm in the present, by definition I'm not worried about the future.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A simple mental model for reducing speaking anxiety by shifting attention from future outcomes to the present moment.

quotes.topic_title: Tongue twisters, warmups, and strategic swearing
quotes.text: We have this mistaken notion that we can go from silence to brilliance without warming up.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that encourages speakers to treat voice warmups like athletic warmups rather than optional extras.

quotes.topic_title: Tongue twisters, warmups, and strategic swearing
quotes.text: Tongue twisters for me are a great way to get present oriented. You can't say it right if you don't say the tongue twister if you're not focused on the present moment. And it also warms up your voice.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A practical technique that simultaneously forces focus and prepares the voice before speaking.

quotes.topic_title: Tongue twisters, warmups, and strategic swearing
quotes.text: This is my favorite tongue twister. It takes five seconds to say, it's three phrases long. And if you say it wrong, you say a naughty word.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A concrete, memorable example of a warmup designed to heighten attention through stakes and time-bounded practice.

quotes.topic_title: Tongue twisters, warmups, and strategic swearing
quotes.text: Well, the last one I'll say is, and this one is another one that falls in the kind of funny category, but there's research that says that when you swear, curse, it actually helps you reduce anxiety.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A counterintuitive research-backed claim that strategic swearing can reduce anxiety (with implied context caveats).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The Brady Bunch advice is not good advice.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Challenges the common but unhelpful trope of imagining the audience naked as a way to reduce speaking anxiety.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This notion of visualization as a tool of desensitization actually can be very helpful, but you're not visualizing the audience half naked.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Reframes visualization into a practical anxiety-reduction method grounded in desensitization rather than gimmicks.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So just like a pilot might do a flight simulator, having a visualization can actually really help you feel more comfortable and confident.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Provides a memorable mental model for treating visualization as a rehearsal simulator for high-stakes speaking.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And by taking yourself through that you in essence are a dress rehearsal even though you're not physically in the room.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Gives an actionable way to use visualization: mentally rehearse the full arc of the event to reduce novelty and anxiety.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And the bottom line is this, what you're doing for yourself is making sure it's not new and novel.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Summarizes the core mechanism: reducing novelty increases confidence and a sense of control in speaking situations.

quotes.topic_title: Why spontaneous speaking matters and is learnable
quotes.text: the vast majority of our communication, the plan presenting, the practiced pitch, the meeting with agenda pale in comparison to the times that we are spontaneously speaking.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Reframes where most real-world speaking happens—on the spot—so practitioners prioritize training for spontaneity, not just rehearsed presentations.

quotes.topic_title: Why spontaneous speaking matters and is learnable
quotes.text: the first thing that is important for everybody to know is we can all get better at it. That's the fundamental bottom line.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Establishes a growth mindset foundation: spontaneous speaking is a learnable skill rather than an innate talent.

quotes.topic_title: Why spontaneous speaking matters and is learnable
quotes.text: The second big point to make is you actually have to prepare to be spontaneous.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A counterintuitive principle that turns “winging it” into a practice-based discipline.

quotes.topic_title: Why spontaneous speaking matters and is learnable
quotes.text: if you think about an athlete, when an athlete is doing their sport, they are being spontaneous, they are responding to the conditions that present themselves to them. What helps them do well is all the preparation and practice that they've done.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Provides an actionable analogy (athletics) to justify deliberate practice as the path to better improvisational communication.

quotes.topic_title: Why spontaneous speaking matters and is learnable
quotes.text: The only way I have found to help people get better at this is to look at how we approach it, our mindset, and then how we actually craft the messages through structure and focus that help us be better.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Offers a practical two-part methodology: improve both mindset/approach and message construction (structure and focus).

quotes.topic_title: Using structure to think and speak clearly
quotes.text: In spontaneous speaking, most of us, because we feel the intense pressure, the anxiety we just talked about, we just spew out information, we list and itemize information.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Highlights a common failure mode under pressure—defaulting to unstructured lists—setting up why structure matters.

quotes.topic_title: Using structure to think and speak clearly
quotes.text: In fact, Lenny, how many items do you need to buy from the grocery store before you actually have to physically write it down? For me it's four. Anything over four, I'm going to forget something.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Uses a concrete, memorable example to show how quickly lists exceed working memory limits.

quotes.topic_title: Using structure to think and speak clearly
quotes.text: Our brains are actually wired for story, for connection, a logical connection of ideas.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A mental model for why structured narratives outperform itemized information in comprehension and recall.

quotes.topic_title: Using structure to think and speak clearly
quotes.text: Most advertisements are set up as problem, solution, benefit. There's some problem in the world, here's how we solve it with our product or service, and here's how you benefit from it.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Provides a ready-to-use structure (problem-solution-benefit) practitioners can apply immediately when speaking on the spot.

quotes.topic_title: Using structure to think and speak clearly
quotes.text: When you're put on the spot, you have to think about what to say and how to say it. The structure tells you how to say it, and then you just have to think about what to put into it.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Actionable advice: use structure to reduce cognitive load by separating delivery from content generation.

quotes.topic_title: Practical frameworks: PREP and What-So what-Now what
quotes.text: I love prep and the structure I really like is a three-question structure: What? So what? Now what?
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Introduces a simple, repeatable 3-question framework for structuring communication in product/work contexts.

quotes.topic_title: Practical frameworks: PREP and What-So what-Now what
quotes.text: What is your product, your service, your offering, your update, your feedback? It's the what of why you're speaking. The so what is why is this important and relevant to the people you're talking to or to your company or to prospective clients? And then the now what is what comes next.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Defines each component of What/So what/Now what so practitioners can apply it immediately to any message.

quotes.topic_title: Practical frameworks: PREP and What-So what-Now what
quotes.text: So on a product team, if you're describing a feature, here's what the feature is, here's why it's important, and here's what we're doing about it. If you're giving an update in an update meeting, a standup that you're having, here's what I'm working on, here's why it's important, here's what I'm doing next.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Gives concrete examples of how to use the framework for feature descriptions and standup updates.

quotes.topic_title: Practical frameworks: PREP and What-So what-Now what
quotes.text: By packaging the information up in what, so what, now what, it becomes much more digestible, much more memorable.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Explains the practical benefit of structured messaging: improved clarity and recall for the audience.

quotes.topic_title: Practical frameworks: PREP and What-So what-Now what
quotes.text: Prep works really well for a point you're making. What, so what, now what works really well for a broader presentation, update, feedback session that you're giving.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Provides a decision rule for choosing between frameworks based on the communication situation.

quotes.topic_title: Remembering structures: practice, reflection, feedback
quotes.text: So part of it is just coming up with a mnemonic that works for you and you can name them whatever you want, but really the way to get familiar with them and to have them at the ready is to use them.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A practical method for remembering speaking frameworks: name them memorably, then build fluency through repeated use.

quotes.topic_title: Remembering structures: practice, reflection, feedback
quotes.text: When I coach people on what, so what, now what, I encourage them at the end of a podcast they listen to or something they read, take a moment and say, "What was it about? Why is it important to me and what can I do with that information?"
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A simple 30-second drill to practice a structure while also improving comprehension and retention.

quotes.topic_title: Remembering structures: practice, reflection, feedback
quotes.text: The only way you get better at communication, spontaneous or planned, is the way you get better at anything. Repetition, reflection, and feedback.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A memorable improvement model that reframes communication skill-building as a trainable practice loop.

quotes.topic_title: Remembering structures: practice, reflection, feedback
quotes.text: We are not always the best judges of our communication.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that self-assessment is unreliable, making external feedback essential.

quotes.topic_title: Remembering structures: practice, reflection, feedback
quotes.text: It is work. There is no shortcut.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: A blunt, quotable constraint that sets expectations for what it takes to improve communication.

quotes.topic_title: Where to practice: Toastmasters and improv
quotes.text: I think Toastmasters is a wonderful organization designed primarily to give you the reps.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Highlights a practical, repetition-driven way to build speaking skill through structured practice.

quotes.topic_title: Where to practice: Toastmasters and improv
quotes.text: When people hear improv, they think, "Oh, I got to be funny and it's about performing," and it's not.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Challenges the common misconception that improv is about comedy rather than communication skill-building.

quotes.topic_title: Where to practice: Toastmasters and improv
quotes.text: Improv is really just about being more comfortable, being present, and really focusing on collaborating with others.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Provides a clear mental model for what improv trains: presence, comfort, and collaboration.

quotes.topic_title: Where to practice: Toastmasters and improv
quotes.text: So I, every quarter teach a class that's open to anybody who registers all over the world. It's virtual. I have students this very quarter who take a class on a Monday night Pacific Time, 7:00 PM. I've got somebody in Egypt, I have somebody in China.
quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.context: Gives a concrete example showing how university extension/continuing studies can be accessible globally for practice.
